node.title: Query Regarding Array Bound Checks and Error Handling in MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am a new MOOSE user and currently learning to use the software.
Before switching to MOOSE, I was working with Abaqus where I often used Fortran subroutines (like UMAT, UEXTERNALDB, UEL, etc.) to implement programmable features.
In Fortran subroutine, I would define arrays as follows:
real(8) :: slip_dir(num_slip_sys)
real(8) :: slip_nor(num_slip_sys)
There, If I accidentally accessed an array element beyond its defined range, the subroutine would either fail to compile or throw a segmentation fault during execution, making it easy to identify the issue and correct it.
In MOOSE, the common practice for defining arrays is:
std::vector<Real> slip_dir(_num_slip_sys); 
std::vector<Real> slip_nor(_num_slip_sys);
However, here,  if I mistakenly access an out-of-bounds index in MOOSE, I don’t get a compile-time or segmentation fault error. Instead, I typically encounter issues like poor convergence, floating-point exceptions, or other runtime errors, but not a clear segmentation fault pointing to the mistake.
My question is: Are there any ways to define arrays, or any specific compiler settings, that would catch out-of-bounds array access during compilation or execution, resulting in a more informative error (like a segmentation fault)?
Your guidance on this would be greatly appreciated.
Thank you for your support!

Hello
If you compile in debug mode (set the environment variable METHOD=dbg ) I have observed it will complain when you access out of bounds. I'm not sure how what compiler option turned that on.
An alternative is to add mooseAssert in your code to check that you do not access out of bound by comparing the index and the size
The assert is only compiled in devel and debug mode so it does not affect the opt mode performance
This won't catch anything at compilation btw. Only execution
This won't catch anything at compilation btw. Only execution

Hi  Giudicelli,
Thankyou for your reply.
Can you give an example on how to add mooseAssert for this case. I looked up in Moose Source files but didn't found any relevant case.

For example
mooseAssert(index<vector.size(), "Accessing out of bounds");

if the condition in the first part of the call is false, then the second argument, a string, is output as an error message
You can use this before indexing into the vector with vector[index]

Thankyou  Giudicelli,
for your help

node.title: Different Outputs and Pre-SMO Residual in Old and New MOOSE Application
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am new to MOOSE and currently in the process of learning how to use it.
I am working with a MOOSE-based application, Rhocp (https://github.com/apatra6/rhocp). When I run MOOSE input files using this Rhocp application, the command line output looks like this:
Time Step 121, time = 7.03415, dt = 0.1
Pre-SMO residual: 3.60514e-05
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m
  Finished Solving                                                                       [�[33m  6.56 s�[39m] [�[33m  143 MB�[39m]

Time Step 122, time = 7.13415, dt = 0.1
Pre-SMO residual: 3.6051e-05
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m
  Finished Solving                    
Since this Rhocp application uses an older MOOSE standard, I created a new Rhocp application using ~/projects/moose/scripts/stork.sh Rhocp and copied the necessary files (materials, auxkernels, userobjects, etc.) from the original version.
However, when I run the same input file using this new Rhocp-opt application, the command line output is different:
Time Step 11, time = 0.00321504, dt = 0.000619174
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m

Time Step 12, time = 0.00395805, dt = 0.000743008
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m

Time Step 13, time = 0.00484966, dt = 0.00089161
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m

Time Step 14, time = 0.00591959, dt = 0.00106993
  Applying predictor with scale factor = 1
�[32m Solve Converged!�[39m
I have the following questions:


Why am I seeing different command line outputs when using the older Rhocp version from this repository compared to the new Rhocp version created using stork.sh, even though I copied the same materials, auxkernels, and other files?


What is the "Pre-SMO residual" displayed in the older version's output? How can I enable or use this feature in the new Rhocp application I created?


I have tried changing the following line in RhocpApp.C in the base folder
  InputParameters params = MooseApp::validParams();
  params.set<bool>("use_legacy_material_output") = false;
  params.set<bool>("use_legacy_initial_residual_evaluation_behavior") = true; // from false
still I am getting the same command line output with this new RhoCp based app.
Further I have noticed that for some problems the convergence with old rhocp-opt is better than new rhocp-opt. I think may be reason is this Pre-SMO residual
Thank you for your help!

Hello
First the default output of residuals might have changed. You will want to turn on more output of residuals in the Outputs block. See the CommonOutputAction for the list of parameters
The pre-SMO residual was an early residual evaluation that was not always necessary. Selecting the legacy behavior should re-establish that residual evaluation.
You can use Debug/show_execution_order=ALWAYS to see this initial residual evaluation happen.
Guillaume
Thankyou Giudicelli for your help

node.title: Help regarding Meaning of Usage of Scaling while defining the displacement variables in MOOSE SolidMechanics Physics type problem
node.bodyText:
Hi Moose Team,
I am a new Moose user and currently learning to use Moose.
I have a doubt regarding defination of variables in the Moose input file.
Ref : https://github.com/apatra6/rhocp/blob/main/examples/tantalum/strain_rate_effect/1e-4ps/bcc_pxtal.i
[Variables]
  [./disp_x]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    scaling = 1e-4
  [../]
  [./disp_y]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    scaling = 1e-4
  [../]
  [./disp_z]
    order = FIRST
    family = LAGRANGE
    scaling = 1e-4
  [../]
[]


I am unable to understand what is the function of scaling parameter while defining the variables for FE problem.
I have referred the MOOSE documentation and source files still didn't understood the purpose of scaling parameter in the defination of variables.
And How do we decide ideal value of scaling parameter.
Kindly help me understanding this concept.

Hello
Scaling is used as a simple preconditioning of the equations. When there are multiple equations, we weight the residuals of the equation for each variable by this scaling factor to make the convergence criterion more fair and/or help with matrix conditioning
This page on porous flow has an explanation
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/convergence.html#46b5c8c6-401d-44a8-80b8-1ae589dcd695

And How do we decide ideal value of scaling parameter.

Experimentally most of the time. You look at the residuals and see if they are orders of magnitude apart, maybe it's worth bringiing them closer together.

Hi Guillaume,
Thank you for your response.
From what I understand, the scaling parameter is particularly useful when solving multiphysics problems in MOOSE. Would it also be beneficial when dealing with single-physics problems, such as mechanics, in MOOSE?
Thank you.

It would because the displacements (the equation for each component) might have very different residuals still. For example a traction test might have much larger residual in the direction of the traction
Thankyou  Guillaume, for your help

node.title: Not-linear interface kernel/ BC
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi, I am trying to set up an interface between two blocks A and B that looks like flux = h(nonlinear var in A, nonlinear var in B).
The closest MOOSE objects I have seen are the InterfaceReaction and InterfaceDiffusion kernels, though as far as I can tell these do not allow arbitrary functions of the nonlinear variables on either side of the interface.
In a previous question I have seen test/src/materials/JumpInterfaceMaterial.C mentioned and have taken a look at it. Would I have to implement something similar to this? Or is there a MOOSE object I am missing? Any guidance here would be appreciated.

Hello
InterfaceReaction and InterfaceDiffusion do not allow for an arbitrary function indeed, but they do allow for the dependence on variables on either side of the interface and are a good example to start from to create your own interface kernel that can handle an arbitrary h function.
Interface kernels are designed to work on interfaces between two subdomains, with a conformal mesh at the interface, and with dependencies on variables defined on one or the other side of the interface
Guillaume

Please help if have an idea about this.
Thankyou

Hi Jason,
I wanted to let you know that I started fresh by removing all the files and trying again.
I’m happy to report that the problem is resolved, and MOOSE compiled successfully this time.
Thank you so much for your help and support.

Glad you got it sorted. Not sure what the underlying issue was. The only thing that comes to mind if deleting (rm -rf moose) worked, is that somehow the first build was incorrect and required a cleaning before another attempt could be made. Usually we tell folks to cd moose; git clean -xfd in order to do this.
Cheers! 🍻

node.title: Problems of using MOOSE with hip
node.bodyText:
Hello, just the other week I successfully ran a couple of MOOSE cases using MOOSE (HIP) in an offline environment.#27635 (comment)
I was going to try to run my files using hip, but there were some issues and I'm now opening another discussion.
This is the.i file
[Mesh]
  [gen]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    xmin = 0
    xmax = 1.0
    ymin = 0
    ymax = 1.0
    nx = 16
    ny = 16
  []
[]

[Modules]
  [IncompressibleNavierStokes]
    equation_type = steady-state

    velocity_boundary = 'bottom right top             left'
    velocity_function = '0 0    0 0   lid_function 0  0 0'
    initial_velocity = '1e-15 1e-15 0'
    add_standard_velocity_variables_for_ad = false

    pressure_pinned_node = 0

    density_name = rho
    dynamic_viscosity_name = mu

    use_ad = true
    laplace = true
    family = LAGRANGE
    order = FIRST

    add_temperature_equation = true
    fixed_temperature_boundary = 'bottom top'
    temperature_function = '1 0'

    supg = true
    pspg = true
  []
[]


[Materials]
  [const]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'rho mu cp k'
    prop_values = '1  1  1  .01'
  []
[]

[Functions]
  [lid_function]
    # We pick a function that is exactly represented in the velocity
    # space so that the Dirichlet conditions are the same regardless
    # of the mesh spacing.
    type = ParsedFunction
    expression = '4*x*(1-x)'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Steady
  solve_type = 'NEWTON'
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type -sub_pc_factor_levels -ksp_gmres_restart'
  petsc_options_value = 'asm      6                     200'
  line_search = 'none'
  nl_rel_tol = 1e-12
  nl_max_its = 6
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]


And then this is an error
[LOG_ERROR] ROCR-Runtime_5.2_docker/src/core/runtime/interrupt_signal.cpp:135: Create events pool failed. return value: 0x1

[LOG_ERROR] ROCR-Runtime_5.2_docker/src/core/runtime/interrupt_signal.cpp:135: Create events pool failed. return value: 0x1

[LOG_ERROR] ROCR-Runtime_5.2_docker/src/core/runtime/interrupt_signal.cpp:135: Create events pool failed. return value: 0x1

[LOG_ERROR] ROCR-Runtime_5.2_docker/src/core/runtime/interrupt_signal.cpp:135: Create events pool failed. return value: 0x1

[LOG_ERROR] ROCR-Runtime_5.2_docker/src/core/runtime/interrupt_signal.cpp:135: Create events pool failed. return value: 0x1



*** ERROR ***
/opt/projects/fish/example1/./ad_lid_driven_action_stabilized_steady.i:14.1: section '[Modules]' does not have an associated "Action".
 Common causes:

node.title: Nucleation at specific location in polycrystal
node.bodyText:
Hello,
I want to know if there is a way I can define (in my input file) that if certain variable reaches a particular value (eg. one of the order parameter say eta, when it is 0.5, or if a concentration variable, c, reaches say a value of 0.5) the nucleation takes place at those regions only. I am using DiscreteNucleationForce but this kernel wants me to act on the reserved order parameter. I am not able to see any module that let me define the condition.
Looking forward.
Thank you
Ashish

Hello
I think this is a use case the grain tracker.
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/postprocessors/GrainTracker.html
Guillaume
Thank you

node.title: Outputting the last time step
node.bodyText:
Hello team,
I am using time_step_interval option to create output files at an interval. With this, I noticed that the last time step does not always get written because of the above option. How can I get the last time step irrespective of what time_step_interval I use?

Hello
You can add the execute_on  FINAL option to the output.
So probably set the parameter as execute_on = 'TIMESTEP_END FINAL'
Guillaume

node.title: Error with Flow Channel Scaling Factor
node.bodyText:
Hello, I am working on simulating a case where a pipe splits into 10 pipes, they go through a heated section, then recombine into 1 pipe. What I am trying to do I modify the scaling_factor_1phase for a flow channel 1 phase, however, whenever I define scaling_factor_1phase, I get a terminal error that says: "The variable 'rhoA' has already been added with a different scaling factor.", however, I do not have this defined elsewhere. Below is my current input file.
`# Define regen properties.
L_regen = 1
n_elems_regen = 10
D_regen = 0.005
[GlobalParams]
initial_p = 1e6
initial_T = 60
initial_vel = 1.0
initial_vel_x = 1
initial_vel_y = 0
initial_vel_z = 0
fp = fp

closures = simple_closures
f = 0

gravity_vector = '0 0 0'

[]
[FluidProperties]
[fp]
type = IdealGasFluidProperties
gamma = 1.4
molar_mass = 0.01
[]
[]
[Closures]
[simple_closures]
type = Closures1PhaseTHM
[]
[]
[Components]
[inlet_1]
type = InletMassFlowRateTemperature1Phase
input = 'pipe_1:in'
m_dot = 5
T = 100
[]
[pipe_1]
    type = FlowChannel1Phase
    position = '0 0 0'
    orientation = '0 1 0'
    length = 1
    n_elems = 10
    A = 1
    scaling_factor_1phase = '0.1 0.1 0.1'
[]

[regen_hs]
    type = HeatStructureCylindrical
    position = '0 0 0'
    orientation = '0 1 0'
    length = ${L_regen}
    n_elems = ${n_elems_regen}
    names = 'block'
    widths = '${fparse D_regen / 2.}'
    solid_properties = 'steel'
    solid_properties_T_ref = '300'
    n_part_elems = 5
[]

[total_pwr_regen]
    type = TotalPower
    power = 2000
[]

[regen_heating]
    type = HeatSourceFromTotalPower
    hs = regen_hs
    regions = block
    power = total_pwr_regen
[]

[regen_ht]
    type = HeatTransferFromHeatStructure1Phase
    flow_channel = pipe_1
    hs = regen_hs
    hs_side = outer
    P_hf = '${fparse pi * D_regen}'
[]

[jct1]
    type = JunctionParallelChannels1Phase
    position = '0 1 0'
    connections = 'pipe_1:out pipe_2:in'
    volume = 1e-5
[]

[pipe_2]
    type = FlowChannel1Phase
    position = '0 1 0'
    orientation = '0 1 0'
    length = 1
    n_elems = 10
    A = 1
    # scaling_factor_1phase = '0.1 0.1 0.1'
[]

[outlet]
    type = Outlet1Phase
    input = 'pipe_2:out'
    p = 1e6
[]

[]
[Preconditioning]
[pc]
type = SMP
full = true
[]
[]
[Executioner]
type = Transient
scheme = bdf2
start_time = 0
dt = 0.1
num_steps = 5000

abort_on_solve_fail = true

solve_type = 'newton'
line_search = 'basic'
petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
petsc_options_value = ' lu'

nl_rel_tol = 1e-6
nl_abs_tol = 1e-5

nl_max_its = 5
l_tol = 1e-4

[]
[Outputs]
exodus = true
[console]
    type = Console
    outlier_variable_norms = false
[]
print_linear_residuals = false

[] `
Could this error be coming from the heat structure by any chance? When the heat structure is removed from the input file, I get no error, but when it is added, the error appears.

The "different scaling factor" it refers to is the one used on your other channel (pipe_2), which is using a default value that is different from your 0.1 value in pipe_1, so you need to have these match.

If I had a system of pipes, would they all have to have the same scaling factor, or only the pipes on either side of the heated section?
I am curious because only the heated section splits into multiple pipes for better heat flow, but external to the heated sections, the piping is all in one pipe.

Right now, all pipe components, heated or unheated, need to have the same scaling factor. This is because a given variable name like rhoA in the nonlinear system of equations may only have a single scaling factor. There is no ability right now to have that scaling factor differ by block/subdomain. For CONSTANT MONOMIAL variables like we use in THM's flow formulation, this might be possible, but for nodal variables, it wouldn't make since because nodes can be shared between subdomains.
What is your objective in modifying the scaling factor from the default?

Oh ok, I see what you mean. I am trying to modify the scaling factor specifically for heated sections because the total heat generated from the source needs to be distributed between a given number of pipes; without the scaling, the average surface temperature of the pipes do not make sense for the problem I am simulating. Is there another way this could potentially be done in MOOSE? And what would be considered as a CONSTANT MONOMIAL variable - would there be specific components used for that? Thank you for your help so far!

Are you suggesting that the scaling factor is actually affecting the solution? To clarify, the scaling factor gets applied to the equations associated with that variable in the nonlinear system of equations, so in theory it should only affect

conditioning of the linear system
convergence criteria

So it should have numerical effects only, not effects to the governing equations.
If you are trying to change terms in the equations, then this is done elsewhere (let me know if this is the case). If you are not trying to modify terms in the equations and you are seeing solution differences with different scaling factors, it is likely because you are inadvertently changing convergence criteria.
So you have a 2D heat structure, and you want to split the heat between flow channels? What is the physical situation you are trying to model?

Yes, that is correct.; the model is currently set up for heat regen for a nuclear thermal engine. The pipes split off and wrap around the nozzle, gaining heat energy from conduction with the outer surface. We may try using a scaled up area approach for the time being to see how that works. Thank you for your help in clarifying!
